I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  This regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) is designed to address 
issues affecting gender equality in the legal and other related sectors and to fill significant gaps 
among institutions. It aims to build a stronger, more inclusive society by (i) strengthening the 
capacity of investigating, prosecuting, and decision-making bodies; and (ii) informing women of 
their rights, enabling them to access social and legal justice. It also aims to use existing networks 
and initiatives to achieve a nationwide outreach. The TA will help participating countries fulfill their 
obligations under the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against 
Women (CEDAW), among others. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
2.  The TA will be conducted in Afghanistan and Pakistan, with the possibility of expanding to 
Tajikistan. Activities will be implemented independently in each participating country, keeping in 
mind how organizations in each country can collaborate with or learn from each other. 
 
3.  In its Gender Equality and Women’s Empowerment Operational Plan, 2013–2020: Moving 
the Agenda Forward, the Asian Development Bank (ADB) recognizes that without harnessing the 
talents, human capital, and economic potential of the women and girls who make up half of Asia’s 
population, it will not realize its goal of a region free of poverty.2 The plan adopts gender 
mainstreaming as the key strategy to promote gender equality and women’s empowerment 
across all ADB operations. In 2016, countries will adopt the Sustainable Development Goals, 
which for the first time include a target for eliminating gender-based violence (GBV). 
 
4.  ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2009–2013 for Afghanistan (extended by the interim 
country partnership strategy, 2014–2015) lists gender and development as a priority.3 ADB’s 
country partnership strategy, 2015–2019 for Pakistan acknowledges that large gender inequities 
remain and states that ADB support directly impacts women’s empowerment and well-being.4 
ADB’s country partnership strategy, 2010–2014 for Tajikistan (extended by the interim country 
partnership strategy, 2015) identifies gender mainstreaming as a cross-cutting theme for ADB 
interventions.5 
 
II.  ISSUES 
5.  Typical issues include the following: (i) a dearth of research and data on the prevalence 
of GBV; (ii) poor understanding, awareness, or misinterpretation of women’s legal rights; (iii) lack 
of access to information about available legal procedures and services; (iv) lack of gender 
sensitivity in the judiciary and the legal profession toward women’s legal rights; (v) inadequate 
legal aid to facilitate women’s access to justice; (vi) inadequate institutional mechanisms; (vii) lack 
of coordination among key stakeholders; and  (viii) the existence of parallel legal systems, 
including mainstream courts, sharia courts, the panchayt (village council), and the jirga (traditional 
assembly of leaders).

6.  Pakistan. The sixth most populous country in the world, Pakistan has a population of 
185.1 million as of 2014, 48.6% of which is female.6 Institutional mechanisms to support gender-
equality laws and policies exist at all levels of government, and the 1973 Constitution—Articles 
25 and 28 in particular—legally mandates gender equality along with other human rights.7 
Pakistan has also ratified all relevant United Nations (UN) treaties, including CEDAW. The 
Ministry of Women Development was established as the primary national mechanism to advance 
women and implement CEDAW, tasks that have since been devolved to the provinces through 
the creation of women development departments. A National Commission on the Status of 
Women  was  also  formed  to  combat  discrimination  against  women  in  compliance  with  the 
country’s international obligations.8 In 2008, the Ministry of Human Rights (MOHR) was created 
under the Ministry of Law and Justice, which is now the Ministry of Law, Justice and Human 
Rights.9 The 18th amendment to the Constitution appointed the MOHR to deal with human rights 
and women’s empowerment. These responsibilities were delegated to the Ministry of Law and 
Justice after the dissolution of the MOHR. 
 
7.  GBV in Pakistan is pervasive across class, religion, ethnicity, and the urban and rural 
divide, being rooted in a patriarchal social structure in which women are viewed as property and 
subservient to men.10 In 2009, a civil society organization (CSO) reported 8,548 cases of GBV, 
citing a 13% increase from the previous year (footnote 10). The same study noted that police 
records show 79,909 reported cases of GBV during 2000–2010 (footnote 10). In 2013, the MOHR 
recorded 7,372 human rights violations, the majority of which involved honor killings, rapes, acid 
attacks, domestic violence, and sexual harassment.11 In terms of gender equity, Pakistan falls far 
behind even the war-torn countries of Syria and Sudan.12 Women earn 21% less and receive 43% 
fewer educational opportunities than men. The rate of female participation in the labor force was 
26.4% in 2013, one of the lowest in Asia. Pakistan’s gender equality legislation is minimally 
adequate and implementation remains weak due to several factors, including weak public sector 
capacity, limited resources, and social and cultural constraints. 
 
8.  Afghanistan. Afghanistan’s population as of 2014 was around 31.28 million, of which 49.3% 
is female. The 2004 Constitution of Afghanistan—Articles 7, 22, 54, and 130 in particular—sets 
out the legal framework for the protection and advancement of human rights, including women’s 
rights. 13  The  Elimination  of  Violence  Against  Women  (EVAW)  Law  passed  in  2009  is 
Afghanistan’s primary legislation on GBV and women’s issues. The Ministry of Women’s Affairs 
established in 2001 is responsible for implementing the government’s political and social policies 
to secure and expand the legal rights of women and ensure the rule of law in their lives.14 The 
Afghanistan Independent Human Rights Commission (AIHRC) established in 2002  aims to 
monitor, foster, and protect human rights in Afghanistan. Afghanistan is a party to CEDAW, as 
well as other significant international treaties.

9.  Violence against women is considered a widespread and undeniable reality in Afghan 
society.15 According to a 2008 national survey by Global Rights Afghanistan, 87.2% of Afghan 
women and girls face at least one form of sexual, physical, economic, and psychological abuse.16 
The AIHRC reported that 6,611 cases were presented to its office in 2013, an increase of 16% 
from the previous year (footnote 15). Women and men are widely divided by certain traditions, 
practices, and perceptions of responsibilities. The rate of female labor force participation in 2013 
was estimated at 16%, the lowest in Asia.17 While EVAW is considered a significant achievement, 
its implementation remains challenging as the majority of law enforcement agencies are not fully 
aware of this law nor of their obligations with respect to it. Women themselves are either unaware 
or lack understanding of EVAW. 
 
10.  Tajikistan. Tajikistan's population as of 2014 is 8.4 million, of which 49.8% are women. 
More than 70% of the population lives in rural areas, reflecting the traditionally higher rural birth 
rate and the decline in urban employment.18 Along with other Central Asian states, Tajikistan has 
enshrined the declaration of gender equality in its Constitution and adopted a number of laws in 
2005–2013 to ensure gender equality.19 Under the Constitution, all individuals are equal before 
the law and courts, rights and freedoms are guaranteed, and women and men have equal rights.20 
Tajikistan is also a party to and has ratified CEDAW. 
 
11.   One study found that 62%–72% of Tajik homes experienced domestic violence.21 During 
a 2008 visit to Tajikistan, the UN special rapporteur on violence against women noted that women 
in Tajikistan were caught in a web of poverty, patriarchy, and a weak protective infrastructure, 
resulting in increased vulnerability to violence and discrimination inside and outside their homes.22 
This remains true, despite a female labor force participation rate of 58.9% in 2013. Significant 
barriers preventing women from accessing justice include (i) unwillingness caused by shame to 
involve others in solving disputes; (ii) ignorance of the right to free legal counsel and of the fact 
that the state does not recognize a marriage conducted by a religious person alone; (iii) a lack of 
resources and awareness; (iv) a lack of physical access to justice as many districts are large and 
sparsely populated; and (v) a dearth of lawyers in some areas of the country. 
 
12.  The significant economic and social costs of GBV impact not only women and girls 
personally, but also their families and communities; the government, which provides health care; 
and the economy in general, which suffers from the lack of women’s participation in governance 
and the labor force.

pervasive gender discrimination, GBV, and social and cultural constraints. Improving women’s 
access to and ability to use legal tools will enable more effective and substantive gender 
mainstreaming of ADB investments in every sector. Legal tools and building the capacity of

commitment  to  improve  gender  equity  through  strong  national  strategies,  and  (iii)  ADB’s 
commitment to help the governments achieve their targeted goals as stated in ADB’s country 
partnership strategies. 
 
III.  THE CAPACITY DEVELOPMENT TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
14.  The impact of the TA will be improved access to justice and social and other services for 
women in the participating countries. The outcome will be improved legal literacy with respect to 
gender-based crimes on the part of women; government, legal, and judicial officials; and religious 
and community leaders in the participating countries. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA will involve activities aimed at addressing GBV and discrimination against women 
in the participating countries (Afghanistan, Pakistan, and Tajikistan). Information and training 
modules will be disseminated to communities by leveraging existing local networks for nationwide 
outreach.  Implementing  partners  include  community  organizations,  CSOs,  and  government 
agencies. 
 
16.   Output 1: Increased capacity of the government, civil society organizations, and 
legal and judicial officers to respond to clients on gender issues. This output includes (i) 
conducting  a  situational  analysis  and  needs  assessment  of  institutional  mechanisms  and 
capacities to address women-related issues within the legislative and judicial systems (both 
formal and informal); (ii) providing institutional support and addressing capacity gaps and issues 
by training government officials, legal and judicial officers, and informal dispute resolution experts 
on laws dealing with women, with a particular focus on their responsibilities, as well as on 
techniques and skills required to respond to female victims of violence and discrimination; (iii) 
conducting legal training for women leaders, youth groups, gender equality advocates, and CSOs; 
(iv) developing a compendium of case law relating to GBV (good practices) in English and local 
languages for judges and lawyers; (v) preparing a course and/or curriculum on women’s rights 
and related laws and issues to be taught at law schools and judicial academies;  and (vi) 
conducting any other activity that is considered relevant within the scope of this TA and is needed 
in the participating country. 
 
17.  Output 2: Increased awareness of and support for women’s legal literacy and 
access to legal aid and services. This output includes (i) developing print, electronic, and social 
media campaigns in national and local languages on women’s legal rights, as well as procedures 
and services available for accessing legal aid; (ii) developing simple and reader-friendly materials 
on pro-women laws; (iii) sharing success stories about raising awareness and creating an 
enabling legal environment for women using nontraditional media like text messaging and short 
videos; and (iv) mobilizing existing communities by raising the awareness of government officials,

5 
religious leaders, journalists, CSOs, students, youth groups, and other stakeholders using various 
media, including documentaries. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, which will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-V). ADB will not finance any activity unless it receives 
no objection from the government of the relevant participating country. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.   ADB, through the Office of the General Counsel (OGC) and the Central and West Asia 
Department (CWRD), will be the executing agency for this TA. The partner government agencies 
of the TA will be the Ministry of Law, Justice and Human Rights in Pakistan; the Ministry of 
Women’s Affairs in Afghanistan; and most likely the Committee of Women and Family Affairs 
under the Government of Tajikistan. Relevant organizations or CSOs will be identified during 
project implementation to serve as implementing partners. The OGC will be responsible for 
administering and supervising the TA in general, including the engagement of consultants and 
coordination  with  implementing  partners.  The  CWRD  will  facilitate  the  development  and 
administration of the TA and provide expertise relating to the participating countries during 
implementation. The OGC and CWRD will be jointly accountable for the delivery of the TA outputs. 
The TA will be implemented from 2016 to 2019. 
 
20.  The TA will require the services of three national consultants for 20 person-months each 
to support implementation of the TA in the participating countries. The TA will also require an 
international consultant for 20 person-months. One additional national consultant will be hired in 
Manila for 24 person-months on an intermittent basis to help implement and supervise the TA. 
The consultants will be recruited using the individual selection method or through a consulting 
firm following ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to 
time).23 The procurement of all goods and equipment under the TA will follow ADB’s Procurement 
Guidelines (2015, as amended from time to time). All disbursements under the TA will be made 
in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended 
from time to time). 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
21.   The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $750,000 on a grant basis for 
Legal Literacy for Women, and hereby reports this action to the Board. 
 
23 To reduce the administrative burden and improve economy, efficiency, and value for money, consulting services 
under the TA will be engaged under output-based (lump-sum) contracts, where appropriate.

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Consultants under the regional capacity development technical assistance (TA) will be 
selected in accordance with the Asian Development Bank’s (ADB) Guidelines on the Use of 
Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time). These terms of reference broadly describe 
consultants’ tasks in relation to the implementation of activities under the outputs. 
 
2.   Background. In light of widespread ignorance regarding women-related laws and policies, 
this TA aims to build a stronger and more inclusive society by (i) strengthening the capacity of 
investigating,  prosecuting,  and  decision-making  bodies;  and  (ii)  informing  women  more 
thoroughly of their rights to help them access social and legal justice. Legal tools have proven 
very useful for facilitating social change, empowering women, and supporting better governance. 
Legislative reforms ensuring legal equality and protection for women have been introduced in all 
participating countries. However, women’s literacy is very low and women’s legal literacy is even 
lower. Furthermore, the legal and judicial systems have a fluid attitude regarding legislation and 
the implementation and interpretation of laws in courts. To allow women to benefit from these 
laws, it is important to work closely with law enforcement bodies to ensure understanding and 
proper use of the existing legislative framework. Improving women’s access to and ability to use 
legal  tools,  including  mediation,  will  facilitate  more  effective  and  substantive  gender 
mainstreaming of ADB investments in every sector. 
 
A.  National Consultants (Three Individuals or One Firm) for a Legal Literacy Program 
Under Output 1 (20 person-months each, intermittent) 
 
3.  Qualifications. A national consultant firm or civil society organization (CSO) is preferred, 
particularly  one  with  experience  in  developing  and  running  legal  literacy  programs  in  the 
participating countries, including developing capacity-building and training modules and carrying 
out training sessions. The consultant or head of the firm should have a postgraduate degree in 
social sciences or a relevant field, with at least 10 years of experience in the areas mentioned 
above. Particular preference will be given to organizations with:  
(i)  expertise and work experience related to similar thematic issues and in proposed 
target areas; 
(ii)  experience and skills in awareness and advocacy-led initiatives; 
(iii)  strong  record  of  collaboration  with  allied  federal  and  provincial  government 
departments; and 
(iv)  experience working with the media and other key stakeholders, including police, 
lawyers, judges, and parliamentarians. 
 
4.  Scope of work. The selected firm or CSO will be expected to work in cooperation with the 
TA team leaders to address the issue of violence against women by increasing women’s legal 
literacy and training stakeholders on the legal and judicial systems (both formal and informal). 
The selected firm or CSO will focus primarily on apprising women of laws related to their protection 
and creating an enabling environment in which women can access justice with help from the 
police, the media, lawyers, the judiciary, and medical professionals. 
 
5.  Detailed tasks. Detailed tasks will be determined in accordance with the needs of each 
participating country and will, in part, include: 
(i)  conducting a situational analysis and needs assessment of existing institutional 
mechanisms and the capacity of all relevant stakeholders (including targeted 
communities and women) to address issues related to gender-based violence 
(GBV), including processes and outcomes;

Appendix 3  11 
(ii)  identifying an action plan based on the needs assessment to deal with the capacity 
constraints of relevant stakeholders; 
(iii)  developing training modules based on the needs assessment for key stakeholders, 
including government officials, police and other law enforcement officials, judges, 
mediators, lawyers, medical professionals, the media, and other service providers; 
(iv)  using the modules to train the identified key stakeholders; 
(v)  recording the impact of the training sessions in quarterly reports and mapping the 
progress of trained stakeholders through data collection, surveys, and interviews; 
(vi)  conducting paralegal training where needed for women leaders, youth groups, 
gender equality advocates, and CSOs; 
(vii)  developing and implementing a dissemination plan, leveraging existing networks 
for nationwide outreach, and disseminating information and training modules to 
communities through pre-established rural support and other networks; 
(viii)  conducting  surveys  on  the  impacts  of  disseminating  capacity-development 
materials; 
(ix)  developing a compendium of case law and good practices relating to GBV in 
English and local languages for judges, mediators, and lawyers; 
(x)  preparing a course on women’s rights and related laws and issues to be taught at 
educational institutions, where needed; 
(xi)  developing guidance materials for government and nongovernment institutions to 
improve women’s access to justice by helping to establish and institutionalize GBV 
referral mechanisms for criminal, civil, or informal dispute resolution, as well as 
guiding women as to their options in this respect; 
(xii)  developing training for government and nongovernment mediation organizations 
in Afghanistan on good practice mediation methodology, suggested resolutions, 
good case examples, and the registration of mediation agreements and monitoring 
mechanisms; 
(xiii)  building regional networks of GBV service providers, including mapping services 
and holding regular networking and knowledge-sharing events; 
(xiv)  engaging  with  men  and  the  media  as  stakeholders  to  create  an  enabling 
environment for women to exercise their legal rights, in particular by building 
anonymous profiles of women as survivors rather than victims; 
(xv)  regularly reporting to the TA team leaders on the implementation progress of 
output 1; and 
(xvi)  conducting any other activity agreed upon with the TA team leaders. 
 
B.  Individual Consultant for TA Coordination (national, 24 person-months, intermittent) 
 
6.  Qualifications. The individual consultant must have at least a graduate degree and 
experience working on women-related projects, including women’s legal literacy and media 
campaigns. Preference will be given to a candidate with experience working on ADB TA projects. 
 
7.  Scope of work The consultant is expected to work with the TA team leaders in managing 
and administering the TA activities, and to help them comply with the relevant ADB policies and 
procedures during the TA implementation. 
 
8.  Detailed tasks. The consultant’s detailed tasks will be determined under the supervision 
of the TA team leaders in accordance with the needs of each participating country and will, in part, 
include: 
(i)  helping the team leaders process TA activities within ADB using ADB’s processing 
and implementation policies and obtain necessary approvals from Management;

12  Appendix 3 
(ii)  helping manage TA activities by liaising and coordinating with implementation 
partners in participating countries and ADB development partners, if required; 
(iii)  assisting and supporting the TA team leaders and international and national 
consultants in planning and organizing TA-related events, workshops, and/or 
training sessions; 
(iv)  helping the TA team draft TA-related documents; 
(v)  helping international and national consultants align their reports with ADB formats 
and templates; 
(vi)  reviewing and commenting on TA-related reports and documents, and helping 
research, write, and edit knowledge products that may be published under the TA; 
(vii)  liaising with relevant ADB departments and resident missions on (a) producing and 
publishing  knowledge  products;  (b)  fielding  missions;  (c)  holding  meetings, 
workshops, and/or seminars; and (d) carrying out other, miscellaneous TA-related 
tasks; 
(viii)  helping the TA team leaders obtain approvals and no objections from relevant ADB 
departments and the governments of participating countries; 
(ix)  participating in meetings with the TA team in Manila or any participating country to 
enable the successful implementation of TA activities; 
(x)  supporting regional or country activities planned under the TA; 
(xi)  helping the TA team prepare situational analysis reports, midterm reports, and a 
TA completion report; and 
(xii)  performing other tasks related to achieving the TA outputs and outcomes. 
 
C.  International  Consultant  Firm  or  Organization  for  Developing  a  Legal  Literacy 
Awareness Campaign Through the Media (20 person-months, intermittent) 
 
9.  Qualifications. The international consultant firm or organization must have experience in 
developing and running legal literacy awareness campaigns in the participating countries. The 
consultant or head of the firm should have a postgraduate degree in social sciences or a relevant 
field, with at least 10 years of experience in advocacy and filmmaking. Particular preference will 
be given to organizations with: 
(i)  familiarity with the issues in a regional context, especially in at least two of the 
three participating countries; 
(ii)  at least 5 to 8 years of experience in developing and running media campaigns, 
including documentary and/or film production; 
(iii)  experience in behavioral change techniques; and 
(iv)  comprehension of and communication skills in English, Urdu, Pashto, Dari, and 
Tajik. 
 
10.   Scope of work. The selected firm or organization will be expected to work in coordination 
with the TA team leaders to design and launch innovative communication and behavior-changing 
interventions to improve people’s attitudes and to raise general awareness of women-related laws 
and issues in all participating countries. The international consultant will work with the national 
firm or CSO running the legal literacy program in the participating countries to build on the work 
of this TA. The international consultant will prepare a final documentary on the awareness and 
legal literacy work done under the TA and its impact on communities and other government, legal, 
and judicial stakeholders. 
 
11.   Detailed tasks. Detailed tasks will be determined in accordance with the needs of each 
participating country and will, in part, include:

Appendix 3  13 
(i)  developing a sensitive media campaign with a positive tone to share success 
stories using nontraditional media like text messaging and short videos. The 
campaign aims to (a) educate, inform, and create a positive shift in the behavior of 
people regarding gender equity; (b) evoke a sense of shame in those who do not 
respect  women’s  rights;  and  (c)  target  relevant  audience  segments  with 
appropriate messages through suitable media and communication channels that 
will have the greatest impact  and will deliver the objectives of the TA most 
effectively; 
(ii)  developing a media kit to disseminate information to key stakeholders, including 
government officials, police and other law enforcement officials, judges, mediators, 
lawyers, medical professionals, the media, and other service providers. The kit will 
include flyers, posters, text messages, short videos, and other innovative media to 
highlight how to implement pro-women laws and what society can do to address 
the issue, trigger the audience to behave differently, and draw more people into 
the discussion; 
(iii)  conducting pre-and postcampaign perception research to establish benchmarks 
and measure progress; 
(iv)  conducting training sessions with (a) the national firm or CSO running the legal 
literacy program and (b) the media to align the media campaign with the TA 
objectives; 
(v)  sensitizing different relevant audiences and stakeholders to GBV-related issues 
by developing and disseminating advocacy materials; 
(vi)  producing a documentary or suitable equivalent on the TA activities, the legal 
literacy work in particular, to prevent GBV and help women access justice. The 
documentary aims to generate dialogue around the issue in a culturally relevant 
way  and  to  reach  specific  audiences,  including  the  public,  the  media,  law 
enforcement agencies, and international organizations; 
(vii)  reporting regularly to the TA team leaders on the implementation progress of the 
TA activities; and 
(viii)  carrying out any other activity agreed upon with the TA team leaders. 
 
12.   Reporting. The selected national and international consultants must prepare and submit 
the following reports: 
(i)  a situational analysis report at the beginning of the TA implementation period; 
(ii)  quarterly reports to be submitted to the TA team leaders to demonstrate the 
progress of the design and implementation of the TA activities against agreed 
indicators and milestones; and 
(iii)  a final report to be submitted to the TA team leaders summarizing all TA 
activities, impacts, and lessons learned in a format agreed upon with the team 
leaders.
